I.    TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FOR PROJECT PREPARATION AND 
IMPLEMENTATION 
A.  Justification 
1.  A  transaction  technical  assistance  (TRTA)  is  required  to  (i)  conduct  technical  and 
safeguards due diligence to enhance readiness of the ensuing project, and (ii) support building 
capacity of Bengaluru Electricity Supply Company Limited (BESCOM) in (a) distribution network 
management system and business practices, and (b) environmental safeguard monitoring.  
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
2.  The major outputs and activities are summarized in Table 1.

C.  Cost and Financing 
3.  The TA is estimated to cost $300,000, of which $225,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The key expenditure items 
are listed in Table 2.  
 
4.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office, 
secretarial assistance, domestic transportation, and other in-kind contributions. The government 
was informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project.

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
5.  ADB will administer the TA, and will select, supervise and evaluate consultants. ADB will 
oversight the TA implementation and communicate with consultants and concerned stakeholders.

7.  Consulting services. Two international individual consultants and one national individual 
consultant will be recruited to support technical and safeguards due diligence and monitoring for 
the ensuing loan project, as well as capacity building addressed to the state’s distribution utility 
company. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as 
amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or staff 
instructions. The required positions and person-months are indicated in Table 4. Lump sum 
payments/output-based contracts will be considered under the TA.

8.  The outline terms of reference for TA consultants are described in paras. 9 to 11. 
 
9.  Power Distribution and Communication Specialist (international, 2.5 person-months, 
intermittent). The expert should have (i) minimum bachelor’s degree in electrical engineering 
(Master’s degree is preferable); (ii) at least 10 years of engineering experience or actual working 
experience in power distribution subsector in power utility including senior advisory or managerial 
level; and (iii) a good command of English. The expert will undertake the following activities: 
(i)  Provide suggestions to optimize the technical design for underground power 
distribution  network,  distribution  automation  system,  and  optical  fiber 
communication cables;  
(ii)  Design  knowledge  sharing  events  in  designing,  construction,  operation,  and 
maintenance of underground power distribution system, distribution automation 
system, and underground optical fiber communication system; 
(iii)  Coordinate  with  knowledge  providers,  an  implementing  agency,  and  other 
concerned parties on day-to-day logistical matters in organizing events;  
(iv)  Prepare reports summarizing (a) technical inputs provided to the implementing 
agency by the experts, and recommendations for further improvement, and (b) the 
achievements and lessons learnt from the knowledge sharing events. 
 
10.  Environmental  Impact  Assessment  Specialist  (international,  1.0  person-month, 
intermittent).  The  expert  should  (i)  have  a  postgraduate  degree  in  environmental  science, 
environmental engineering, environmental management, or in any relevant field; (ii) have at least 
10 years of working experience; (iii) have experience in assessing environmental impacts and 
quantifying carbon emission reduction in power sector; (iv) have a good understanding of ADB’s 
Safeguard Policy Statement1 (2009); and (v) be fluent in both spoken and written English. The 
expert will undertake the following activities: 
(i)  Carbon reduction analysis. Assess and quantify environmental benefits, such as 
energy efficiency improvements, carbon emission reduction, and other associated 
environmental benefits, 
(ii)  Conduct  of  impact  assessment.  Assess  the  environment  adverse  impact 
associated with the proposed project, propose a set of environmental mitigation 
measures throughout the project implementation, and recommend international 
best  practices,  environmentally-friendly  options,  avoidance,  minimization  and 
compensatory measures (if required) to address the adverse impacts associated 
with the location, design, construction and operation of the project, emphasizing 
those on (a) biodiversity conservation, (b) occupational and public health and 
safety, (c) physical cultural resources, and (d) pollution prevention and abatement, 
and  ensure  those  aspects  are  documented  and  incorporated  in  an  Initial 
Environmental Examination (IEE) report, which include the following contents,   
•  Identify all the relevant environmental laws, regulations in India and other 
relevant environmental standards used by World Bank or other well-known 
international organizations and determine the most stringent environmental 
standards and regulations that will be applied for various aspects of the project.  
•  Establish environmental baseline indicators and performance targets. 
•  Conduct alternative studies to find the best project scope with least adverse 
environmental impacts.  
•  Prepare a sound and comprehensive Environmental Management Plan (EMP) 
that meets the ADB’s requirements. Ensure that environmental baseline data, 
indicators, and performance targets are incorporated in the EMP. 
 
1 https://www.adb.org/sites/default/files/institutional-document/32056/safeguard-policy-statement-june2009.pdf

4 
•  Assist the executing and implementing agencies in conducting meaningful 
public  consultation  during  preparation  of  an  IEE  report,  which  includes 
information disclosure to affected people and other key stakeholders; recording 
details of these activities; and ensuring that the views and concerns received 
are considered in developing the EMP. 
•  Assist the executing and implementing agencies in establishing a project 
grievance redress mechanism (GRM) to address environmental concerns that 
may be raised by the project-affected people. This includes planning, designing, 
and disseminating the GRM to the likely affected people that meets the ADB 
requirements on GRM. Incorporate GRM system in the IEE report.  
•  Establish environment monitoring items during pre-construction, construction 
and operation, and prepare an environmental monitoring plan (EMP), and 
incorporate it in the EMP.  
•  Prepare a list of activities and budget for the proposed environmental mitigation 
measures and implementation of the EMP during project implementation.  
(iii)  Prepare the IEE report including EMP in English, meeting the requirements of the 
ADB's Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), specifically, safeguard requirements 
(Appendix 1 of Safeguard Policy Statement 2009) and submit it to ADB. 
 
11.  Environmental  Safeguard  Monitoring  Specialist  (national,  4  person-months, 
intermittent). The expert should have (i) at least a master’s degree on environmental management 
or relevant fields; (ii) a minimum of 10 years of experience on environmental management and 
monitoring, including environmental monitoring of thermal power plants, or relevant fields; (iii) 
experience on the supervision of district heating project and operation, or relevant projects; and 
(iv) good communication and report writing skill in English. Experience in projects supported by 
international financial institutions is preferred. The main task of the expert is to supervise the 
implementation of the project’s environment management plans (EMPs) and assist BESCOM in 
preparing environmental monitoring reports. The expert shall be familiar with the World Bank/IFC 
Environment, Health and Safety Guidelines. The expert will undertake the following activities:     
(i)  conduct site visits at least twice a year; 
(ii)  assist  BESCOM  in  updating  the  IEEs  and  EMPs—if  there  are  anticipated 
environmental impacts; 
(iii)  monitor implementation of mitigation measures specified in the EMPs; 
(iv)  collect environmental load data from BESCOM or other government agencies; 
(v)  review monitoring records and environmental performance documents prepared 
by  contractors,  environmental  monitoring  stations,  and  other  relevant 
environmental inspection authorities; 
(vi)  identify  any  environment-related  implementation  issue,  suggest  necessary 
corrective actions, and reflect them in a corrective action plan; 
(vii)  collect other relevant environment indicators to measure the positive environment 
impact (i.e., emissions reduction brought by the project);  
(viii)  conduct quantification and monitoring of greenhouses gas emissions annually in 
accordance with internationally recognized methodologies; and assist EA and IA 
in  preparing  environmental  monitoring  reports  and  semiannually  during 
construction and annual during operation;  
(ix)  provide training on environmental management implementation and monitoring, 
including grievance redress mechanism to staff from BESCOM, contractors, and 
construction supervision companies.
